Do we have any plan to retire py2 entirely? `set_do_not_care_scapy ` were been marked as "deprecated" already, we need to move to `set_do_not_care_packet` eventually

> Do we have any plan to retire py2 entirely? `set_do_not_care_scapy ` were been marked as "deprecated" already, we need to move to `set_do_not_care_packet` eventually

We will keep py2 environment for a long time to support 202012 branch.

> > Do we have any plan to retire py2 entirely? `set_do_not_care_scapy ` were been marked as "deprecated" already, we need to move to `set_do_not_care_packet` eventually
> 
> We will keep py2 environment for a long time to support 202012 branch.

For master branch, now the recommended way is to run tests using python3. For master only changes in the future, we may not always try to make them compatible with python2.

For changes that are required for 202012 branch, we must ensure that those changes are python2 compatible. It's because 202012 branch will keep using python2 to run tests.

Bearing the above background in mind, the python3 environment will move one. Someday we may upgrade the ptf package again. In future ptf package, method `set_do_not_care_scapy` could be totally deprecated. Then we will run into a problem in python3. 

To address such issue, my idea is like below. What do you think? @wsycqyz 

```python
 exp_pkt = mask.Mask(exp_pkt)
 
 if hasattr(exp_pkt, "set_do_not_care_packet"):
 exp_pkt.set_do_not_care_packet(packet.Ether, "dst")
 exp_pkt.set_do_not_care_packet(packet.Ether, "src")
 else:
 exp_pkt.set_do_not_care_scapy(packet.Ether, "dst")
 exp_pkt.set_do_not_care_scapy(packet.Ether, "src")
```

There is another way to hack it. I am not sure if it works. You can try it out:

```python
import ptf.mask as mask

# Fallback to use method set_do_not_care_scapy for older ptf package.
if not hasattr(mask.Mask, "set_do_not_care_packet"):
 mask.Mask.set_do_not_care_packet = mask.Mask.set_do_not_care_scapy
```

This hack is based on the assumption that methods `set_do_not_care_scapy` and `set_do_not_care_packet` take same arguments.

@lerry-lee Wanted to understand little more on this fix.
This change to enable autorestart feature before test is already done here: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/autorestart/test_container_autorestart.py#L38

Why is this additionally required?

If this is done, can we remove the https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/autorestart/test_container_autorestart.py#L38 ?

> @lerry-lee Wanted to understand little more on this fix. This change to enable autorestart feature before test is already done here: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/autorestart/test_container_autorestart.py#L38
> 
> Why is this additionally required?
> 
> If this is done, can we remove the https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/autorestart/test_container_autorestart.py#L38 ?

@SuvarnaMeenakshi 
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/autorestart/test_container_autorestart.py#L38 This was a pre-process before the test script started. And the additional enable autorestart operation is a post-process after one container autorestart and triggered config-reload.

Before testing all containers autorestart, we should enable them autorestart config. There are 2 reasons:
1. If one container is on testing, it should enable this autorestart config
2. Containers have start dependency, if we only enable the testing container, the depend on container may not restart as expected, so maybe caused errors.
Why we required enable autorestart config after a post-check failed is:

After config-reload, the autorestart config for features containers is reset. If for some containers the default set is disabled or some testcases disabled the autorestart config, after config-reload, they are reset to disabled, this may affect the remain testing containers. So only the once previous enable operation is not enough.
